channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: @toebean_peets Grumping about the biology video I tweeted about a moment before. Kind of a note to self, too.
There should be a word for a harder puzzle clue that you don’t actually have to solve because the puzzle context easily fills in the entire answer for you.

Academics often forget easy, powerful links to “read more” pieces, a huge virtue of the web. Academics often forget easy, powerful links to “read more” pieces, a huge virtue of the web. Academics often forget easy, powerful links to “read more” pieces, a huge virtue of the web.

An interesting 60 seconds on farmers fostering healthy soil microbes that build drought resilience, and social scientists playing a role in biological science work. It’s frustrating when academics forget easy, powerful links to “read more” pieces, a huge virtue of the web. https://t.co/BQFbWXReEX
“Every writer needs another set of eyes.” —William Whitworth Quoted in Good Prose: The Art of Nonfiction
Some of the ways of big men. https://t.co/MFZ3dv7nZH
@DLind @jtlevy See, for example, the website of syndicated columnist @AlanGuebert, where each weekly column is followed with a free-standing post with links to source materials.
How to play Novels That Don't Exist. https://t.co/BcCxChvhnZ
The word “official” in their paid promotional tweet is PR advertising bs. Thanks for that, Google! https://t.co/ZquM2U94lR

"Countries can have free speech in their Constitution, but that's not a suicide pact." https://t.co/cl2gC2KhcL
Other uses of that phrase:
https://t.co/Thch6LXGIW
The Bill Barr memoir wants to confirm the basic Trump social media method. https://t.co/m0gE3oaUhS https://t.co/NAQH3NNSFI

Self before country . . . In Jeffrey Toobin’s NYT review of the new Bill Barr memoir, another major Republican lets a good chunk of time pass before daring to speak more forthrightly about the Big Guy. https://t.co/hNCEmyhFTe
Barr’s book title, “One Damn Thing After Another,” is a self-pitying, idea-free synonym for “Sure Was Hard Being Me” . . .
Ah, Barr’s grim view of the noble calling of public service . . .
@dwaynebetts Very curious to know your first word there...

Herodotus expressed a careful formulation about the tragedy of war maybe 2450 years ago, and 50 years ago my uncle, a car mechanic and a veteran of World War II, gave my cousins similar advice. Via Quotomania #117 and Paul @Holdengraber. https://t.co/0ZtHLP9lOP

Our reclusive neighbor is friendly if YOU start the conversation. On his dog walks, he gives a piece of his mind to owners who let their dog off leash in the schoolyard, and he carries a long yellow whiffle ball bat in case he needs to discourage another dog from approaching.

@KevinWagnerPhD I was scrolling down your list of columns, nice to see. I’m always on the lookout for clues to a potent citizens toolkit, beyond voting. Kinds of knowledge, attitudes, skills, tools, types of affiliations and partnerships for creating a civic voice with reach and staying power.

I hope these scholars will write op-eds and record podcasts for wide general audiences about the practical insights that might help us improve the health of our teetering civic institutions. What kind of citizens’ toolkit is called for, eg.? https://t.co/vU4m7macfh

“The idea of a personal intellectual database” goes back a long way . . . https://t.co/V8qQWF5ysz
The personal side of the virtue of hearing other voices. @Charley_Locke https://t.co/tmG746Z4Wf
I wonder if there are commonplace books that have played a role in someone’s activism . . .
A #SundaySentence by Canetti: ‘The most imprecise word of all: I.’ From Not To Read by Alejandro Zambra.
"Russia will be pariah until Putin is gone." A brief thread from @Kasparov63 about the virtue of saying things aloud. https://t.co/GZ7jgEhFyz

A friend living not quite half the world away was invited to a reception there for our Governor (visiting soon on "official" business). Not sure, but I think my friend has a better chance of actually talking to our Governor than most citizens living in Indiana do. How about that?

"You think you have seen the world," she said to a group of U.S. academics. "You have not seen the world. Where you live is not the world. Where I work, near the Mexican border, is also not the world, but one can see the world from there. Come visit me, and I will show you."

@davewiner Poet William Stafford described something like warming up, too, in his daily writing practice, as if the brain is not much like a light switch or bulb. He would jot notes on some very low-pressure thing—to relax and to get the synapses firing, it would seem—and then up the ante.

“The museum should not..blindly reinforce the lack of context typical of social media, but rather should use the breadth of its collection to add depth to our digitally informed ways of seeing…” https://t.co/wzTnmMgcMd

“To those who do not know that the world is on fire, I have nothing to say.” —Bertolt Brecht https://t.co/e7LIrmSt0y & Paul @Holdengraber. Privilege is not having to know, not seeming to know, not being seen to know, not having folks point out what you surely know.
